unnormalised: IIT Delhi's robotics department has announced a breakthrough in AI-powered drone technology. The project, funded by a Rs. 2.5 crore grant from the Ministry of Electronics and IT, aims to develop drones capable of autonomous navigation and object recognition in complex urban environments. Dr. Amit Sharma, the lead researcher, stated that the drones can currently operate for approximately 45 minutes on a single charge.
normalised: I-I-T Delhi's robotics department has announced a breakthrough in A-I-powered drone technology. The project, funded by a rupee two point five crore grant from the Ministry of Electronics and I-T, aims to develop drones capable of autonomous navigation and object recognition in complex urban environments. Doctor Amit Sharma, the lead researcher, stated that the drones can currently operate for approximately forty five minutes on a single charge.

unnormalised: The drones, designated the "Indra Mk. I", are equipped with a suite of sensors, including LiDAR and high-resolution cameras, enabling them to create detailed 3D maps of their surroundings. They are also programmed to identify obstacles such as power lines and buildings. Initial tests were conducted in controlled environments at the IIT campus and subsequently in select areas of Delhi, including Connaught Place and Hauz Khas Village, under strict regulatory supervision.
normalised: The drones, designated the "Indra Mark One", are equipped with a suite of sensors, including L-i-D-A-R and high-resolution cameras, enabling them to create detailed three-D maps of their surroundings. They are also programmed to identify obstacles such as power lines and buildings. Initial tests were conducted in controlled environments at the I-I-T campus and subsequently in select areas of Delhi, including Connaught Place and Hauz Khas Village, under strict regulatory supervision.

unnormalised: One potential application highlighted by the team is disaster relief. The drones could be deployed in disaster-stricken areas, like after a flood in Assam, to assess damage and locate survivors. They could also be used for infrastructure inspection, such as checking the condition of bridges and pipelines. Dr. Sharma added, "We are aiming to have the Indra Mk. I commercially available by Q4 2025."

unnormalised: The technology is expected to be showcased at the upcoming Robotics India Expo in Mumbai on 15/12/2024. Several domestic and international companies have already expressed interest in collaborating with IIT Delhi to further develop and commercialize the technology. The team estimates the market potential for such drones in India to be around $100 million by 2030.
